Detailed Description

Macro Definition Documentation

◆ AM_BLE_NUM_PATCH_CMP_TRIALS

#define AM_BLE_NUM_PATCH_CMP_TRIALS   5000

Patch complete can also take some time.

◆ AM_BLE_NUM_PATCH_TRIALS

#define AM_BLE_NUM_PATCH_TRIALS   5000

The BLE core takes a little while to wake up from a fresh boot, which means that the patch_apply function might time-out on the first few tries. Set this variable to let it try again for a finite number of trials.

◆ AM_BLE_STATUS_TIMEOUT

#define AM_BLE_STATUS_TIMEOUT   300

How long the MCU should wait for SPI_STATUS before assuming the BLE core is busy (measured in 10 us increments).

◆ AM_BLE_TX_PACKET_SPACING_US

#define AM_BLE_TX_PACKET_SPACING_US   1

SPI "options"

These values affect the behavior of the BLE HAL in regards to the SPI bus, but end users aren't likely to need to modify them. They are collected here for testing and debugging purposes. The amount of extra delay to add between successive SPI TX packets (in microseconds).

◆ AM_BLEIF_INT_B2MACTIVE

#define AM_BLEIF_INT_B2MACTIVE   AM_REG_BLEIF_INTEN_B2MACTIVE_M

The B2M_STATE went into the active state.

◆ AM_BLEIF_INT_CQUPD

#define AM_BLEIF_INT_CQUPD   AM_REG_BLEIF_INTEN_CQUPD_M

CQ write operation performed a register write with the register address bit 0 set to 1. The low address bits in the CQ address fields are unused and bit 0 can be used to trigger an interrupt to indicate when this register write is performed by the CQ operation.

◆ AM_BLEIF_INT_DCMP

◆ am_hal_ble_buffer

#define am_hal_ble_buffer (   A)
Value:
union \
{ \
uint32_t words[(A + 3) >> 2]; \
uint8_t bytes[A]; \
}

◆ AM_HAL_BLE_CHK_HANDLE

#define AM_HAL_BLE_CHK_HANDLE (   h)
Value:
((h) && ((am_hal_handle_prefix_t *)(h))->s.bInit \
&& (((am_hal_handle_prefix_t *)(h))->s.magic == AM_HAL_MAGIC_BLE))
AM_HAL_MAGIC_BLE
#define AM_HAL_MAGIC_BLE
Private types.
Definition: am_hal_ble.c:104
am_hal_handle_prefix_t
Definition: am_hal_global.h:145

◆ AM_HAL_BLE_INT_B2MSHUTDN

◆ AM_HAL_BLE_INT_CQUPD

#define AM_HAL_BLE_INT_CQUPD   BLEIF_INTEN_CQUPD_Msk

CQ write operation performed a register write with the register address bit 0 set to 1. The low address bits in the CQ address fields are unused and bit 0 can be used to trigger an interrupt to indicate when this register write is performed by the CQ operation.

#define WHILE_TIMEOUT_MS (   expr,
  timeout,
  error 
)
Value:
{ \
uint32_t ui32Timeout = 0; \
while (expr) \
{ \
if (ui32Timeout >= (timeout * 1000)) \
{ \
return error; \
} \
\

ui32Timeout++; \
} \

◆ am_hal_ble_transfer_complete_cb_t

Function pointer for non-blocking ble read callbacks.

Enumeration Type Documentation

◆ am_ble_status_e

enum am_ble_status_e

BLE-specific status values.

Enumerator
AM_HAL_BLE_STATUS_BUS_BUSY 

This error occurs when an HCI read or write function is called while another HCI communication function is already in progress.

AM_HAL_BLE_STATUS_IRQ_LOW 

This error happens when the MCU tries to execute an HCI read, but the BLE core hasn't asserted the BLEIRQ line. Try waiting for a BLEIRQ interrupt, or polling the BLECIRQ bit in the BSTATUS register before calling an HCI read function.

AM_HAL_BLE_STATUS_SPI_NOT_READY 

This error means that the MCU tried to execute an HCI write, but the BLE core didn't assert its SPI_STATUS signal within the allotted timeout. This might mean that there has been some error inside the BLE core. This may require a reboot of the BLE core.

AM_HAL_BLE_REQUESTING_READ 

This error means we were trying to write, but the BLE core has requested a READ instead. We will need to perform a read before we can retry this write.

AM_HAL_BLE_NO_HCI_RESPONSE 

We are expecting an HCI response to a packet we just sent, but the BLE core isn't asserting BLEIRQ. Its software may have crashed, and it may need to restart.

AM_HAL_BLE_FEATURE_DISABLED 

Any of these errors indicate a problem with the BLE hardware that requires a complete restart.

AM_HAL_BLE_SHUTDOWN_FAILED 
AM_HAL_BLE_REGULATOR_FAILED 
AM_HAL_BLE_POWERUP_INCOMPLETE 
AM_HAL_BLE_HCI_PACKET_INCOMPLETE 
AM_HAL_BLE_FIFO_ERROR 
AM_HAL_BLE_32K_CLOCK_UNSTABLE 
AM_HAL_BLE_STATUS_BUS_BUSY 

This error occurs when an HCI read or write function is called while another HCI communication function is already in progress.

AM_HAL_BLE_STATUS_IRQ_LOW 

This error happens when the MCU tries to execute an HCI read, but the BLE core hasn't asserted the BLEIRQ line. Try waiting for a BLEIRQ interrupt, or polling the BLECIRQ bit in the BSTATUS register before calling an HCI read function.

AM_HAL_BLE_STATUS_SPI_NOT_READY 

This error means that the MCU tried to execute an HCI write, but the BLE core didn't assert its SPI_STATUS signal within the allotted timeout. This might mean that there has been some error inside the BLE core. This may require a reboot of the BLE core.

AM_HAL_BLE_REQUESTING_READ 

This error means we were trying to write, but the BLE core has requested a READ instead. We will need to perform a read before we can retry this write.

AM_HAL_BLE_NO_HCI_RESPONSE 

We are expecting an HCI response to a packet we just sent, but the BLE core isn't asserting BLEIRQ. Its software may have crashed, and it may need to restart.

◆ am_hal_ble_boot()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_boot ( void *  pHandle)

Boot the BLE module.

Note
This function performs the complete patching process for the BLE core and returns with the BLE core in HCI mode. If you ask for the default patches your am_hal_ble_config_t structure, then this is the last function you need to call on startup. You don't need to call any of the patching functions.
Parameters
pHandle- Handle for the BLE module.
Returns
BLE status code.

◆ am_hal_ble_config()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_config ( void *  pHandle,
const am_hal_ble_config_t *  psConfig 
)

Configure a BLE module.

Parameters
pHandle- Handle for the BLE module.
psConfig- Pointer to a BLE configuration structure.

This routine performs the necessary configuration steps to prepare the physical BLE interface for operation. This function should be called after am_hal_ble_enable() and before any other BLE operation. The psConfig parameter may be used to set a specific interface clock frequency or modify the FIFO read and write thresholds, but most users will get the best results from the default settings stored in the global configuration structure am_hal_ble_default_config.

Note
This function will only work if the BLE module has previously been enabled.
Returns
BLE status code.

◆ am_hal_ble_default_patch_apply()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_default_patch_apply ( void *  pHandle)

Apply the default manufacturer patch to the BLE core.

Parameters
pHandleHandle for the BLE module.

The BLE core is an independent processor that executes code from an on-board ROM. Its behavior can be altered through "patches" which are binary snippets of code that may be loaded at startup to overlay or replace sections of the original ROM (for instance, to modify trim settings). This function allows the caller to apply one of these patches.

Patches must be applied after the BLE module is enabled and configured, but before standard HCI operation begins. This is the only time where the BLE core is able to accept patch files.

Returns
BLE status code.

◆ am_hal_ble_default_trim_set_ramcode()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_default_trim_set_ramcode ( void *  pHandle)

Set the bandgap voltage, bandgap current, and retention LDO output values.

Set the bandgap voltage, bandgap current, and retention LDO output valuesbased on the tested values stored in non-volatile memory.

Returns
uint32_t

◆ am_hal_ble_deinitialize()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_deinitialize ( void *  pHandle)

De-initialize the internal state variables for the BLE module.

Parameters
pHandle- Handle variable to be de-initialized.
Note
This function invalidates a previously initialized BLE module handle and deletes the contents of the internal state variables associated with it. This could be used in situations where the caller wants to prevent future function calls to a particular BLE module.
Returns
BLE status code.

◆ am_hal_ble_initialize()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_initialize ( uint32_t  ui32Module,
void **  ppHandle 
)

Initialize the internal state variables for the BLE module.

Parameters
ui32Module- Which BLE module to use.
ppHandle- Pointer to a handle variable to be initialized.

This function initializes the internal state variables associated with a particular BLE module and yields a handle that may be used to perform additional operations with that BLE module.

This function must be called before any other BLE module operation.

Returns
BLE status code.

◆ am_hal_ble_nonblocking_transfer()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_nonblocking_transfer ( void *  pHandle,
am_hal_ble_transfer_t *  psTransfer 
)

Complete the patching phase.

Parameters
pHandle- Handle for the BLE module.
psTransfer- pointer to transfer parameters

After the BLE core is enabled and configured, it enters a "patching mode" where it can accept patches from the main CPU. Once all patches have been applied using the am_hal_ble_patch_apply() function. The application must call this function to command the BLE core to switch to standard HCI mode.

Returns
BLE status code.

◆ am_hal_ble_patch_apply()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_patch_apply ( void *  pHandle,
am_hal_ble_patch_t *  psPatch 
)

Patching functions.

Note
The following functions allow the caller to apply "patches" to the BLE core during its startup phase. These are pre-made configuration files that change the operation parameters of the BLE radio. If you have received a patch file from the manufacturer, you may use the am_hal_ble_patch_apply() function during startup to apply these settings to the BLE core. Otherwise, you may skip this step by calling the am_hal_ble_patch_complete() function.

Apply a patch to the BLE core.

Parameters
pHandle- Handle for the BLE module.
psPatch- Pointer to a structure describing the patch.

The BLE core is an independent processor that executes code from an on-board ROM. Its behavior can be altered through "patches" which are binary snippets of code that may be loaded at startup to overlay or replace sections of the original ROM (for instance, to modify trim settings). This function allows the caller to apply one of these patches.

Note
Patches must be applied after the BLE module is enabled and configured, but before standard HCI operation begins. This is the only time where the BLE core is able to accept patch files.
Returns
BLE status code.

◆ am_hal_ble_patch_complete()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_patch_complete ( void *  pHandle)

Complete the patching phase.

Parameters
pHandleHandle for the BLE module.

After the BLE core is enabled and configured, it enters a "patching mode" where it can accept patches from the main CPU. Once all patches have been applied using the am_hal_ble_patch_apply() function. The application must call this function to command the BLE core to switch to standard HCI mode.

Returns
BLE status code.

◆ am_hal_ble_patch_copy_end_apply()

Returns

◆ am_hal_ble_plf_reg_read()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_plf_reg_read ( void *  pHandle,
uint32_t  ui32Address,
uint32_t *  pui32Value 
)

Read a register value directly from the BLE Core.

Parameters
pHandleis the Handle for the BLE module.
ui32Addressis the address of the register.
*pui32Valueis a pointer where the register value will be stored.

This function uses a vendor-specific sequence of blocking HCI commands to read one of the internal registers within the BLE Core. The value stored in this register will be written to the location specified by pui32Value.

This function is mostly used during initial radio setup or for internal test commands. Standard applications will not need to call this function directly.

Note
This function uses multiple blocking HCI commands in sequence. It should not be used in any situation where blocking commands are not desired. Do not use it in applications where interrupt-driven BLE operations have already started.
Returns
BLE status code.

◆ am_hal_ble_plf_reg_write()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_plf_reg_write ( void *  pHandle,
uint32_t  ui32Address,
uint32_t  ui32Value 
)

Write a register value directly to the BLE Core.

Parameters
pHandle- the Handle for the BLE module.
ui32Address- the address of the register.
ui32Value- the value to write.

This function uses a vendor-specific sequence of blocking HCI commands to write one of the internal registers within the BLE Core.

This function is mostly used during initial radio setup or for internal test commands. Standard applications will not need to call this function directly.

Note
This function uses multiple blocking HCI commands in sequence. It should not be used in any situation where blocking commands are not desired. Do not use it in applications where interrupt-driven BLE operations have already started.
Returns
BLE status code.

◆ am_hal_ble_power_control()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_power_control ( void *  pHandle,
uint32_t  ui32PowerState 
)

Enable the BLE module.

Note
Performs the power-up or power-down sequence for the BLE module referred to be pHandle. This should be called after am_hal_ble_initialize(), but before am_hal_ble_config().
Note
The ui32PowerState variable must be set to either AM_HAL_BLE_POWER_ACTIVE or AM_HAL_BLE_POWER_OFF.
Note
After this function is called, the BLE core will be in its startup or "patching" mode.
Parameters
pHandle- Handle for the BLE module.
ui32PowerState- Determines whether BLE is powered on or off.
Returns
BLE status code.

◆ am_hal_ble_sleep_get()

bool am_hal_ble_sleep_get ( void *  pHandle)

Check the sleep behavior of the BLE core.

Parameters
pHandle- is the Handle for the BLE module.

This function uses a vendor-specific sequence of blocking HCI commands to check whether the BLE core is set to go to sleep between BLE transactions. This function will return "true" if BLE sleep is enabled, or "false" if it is disabled.

Note
This function uses multiple blocking HCI commands in sequence. It should not be used in any situation where blocking commands are not desired. Do not use it in applications where interrupt-driven BLE operations have already started.
Returns
BLE status code.

◆ am_hal_ble_sleep_set()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_sleep_set ( void *  pHandle,
bool  enable 
)

Change the sleep behavior of the BLE core.

Set BLE sleep enable/disable for the BLE core.

Parameters
pHandle- the Handle for the BLE module.
enable- sets the desired sleep behavior.
  • 'true' set sleep enable,
  • 'false' set sleep disable

This function uses a vendor-specific sequence of blocking HCI commands to change the default behavior of the BLE core between radio events. Set enable to true to allow the BLE core to sleep between radio events, or false to keep the BLE core awake at all times. The default behavior on startup allows the BLE core to sleep. Most applications will not need to modify this setting.

Note
This function uses multiple blocking HCI commands in sequence. It should not be used in any situation where blocking commands are not desired. Do not use it in applications where interrupt-driven BLE operations have already started.
Returns
BLE status code.

Set one of the trim values for the BLE core.

Parameters

ui32BleCoreAddressis the target address for the trim value.
ui32TrimValueis the trim value to write to the BLE core.
ui32TrimMaskis the trim mask for ui32TrimValue

This function takes a BLE core trim value from the MCU memory and writes it to a trim register in the BLE core.

Returns

◆ am_hal_ble_tx_power_set()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_tx_power_set ( void *  pHandle,
uint8_t  ui32TxPower 
)

Change the TX power setting of the BLE core.

Parameters
pHandle- the Handle for the BLE module.
ui32TxPower- the desired power setting. 0x03->-20dBm 0x04->-10dBm 0x05->-5dBm 0x08->0dBm 0x0F->4dBm

This function uses a vendor-specific sequence of blocking HCI commands to change the TX power setting of the radio.

Note
This function uses multiple blocking HCI commands in sequence. It should not be used in any situation where blocking commands are not desired. Do not use it in applications where interrupt-driven BLE operations have already started.
Returns
BLE status code.

◆ am_hal_ble_wakeup_set()

uint32_t am_hal_ble_wakeup_set ( void *  pHandle,
uint32_t  ui32Mode 
)

Sends a signal to wake up the BLE controller.

Parameters
pHandleis the Handle for the BLE module.
ui32Modeis determines the value of the WAKE signal.

The BLE core needs to be awake before we send data to it. This function sends a signal to the BLE core that tells it that we intend to send it data. When the BLE core wakes up, it will generate a BLECSSTAT interrupt, and the SPISTATUS bit in the BSTATUS register will be set.

Returns
BLE status code.
